title: Episode 24 – David G. Haskell – The Songs of Trees
subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
description: Enjoy this discussion between author David Haskell and podcast host Aaron William Perry – set in close proximity to towering Cottonwoods along the gently flowing Boulder Creek with scores of ducks in the background!
full_transcript:
[7.1s - 12.7s]: Welcome to the Y on Earth communities stewardship and sustainability podcast series.

[13.4s - 18.4s]: Today we are visiting with Professor and author David George Haskell.

[18.8s - 19.2s]: Hi David.

[19.5s - 20.8s]: Hello and it's good to be with you.

[21.0s - 21.6s]: Welcome to the show.

[21.9s - 22.4s]: Thank you.

[23.3s - 29.5s]: David is a British born American biologist author and professor of biology at

[29.5s - 33.3s]: Sohani, the University of the South in Sohani, Tennessee.

[34.4s - 40.0s]: In addition to scientific papers he has written essays, poems, op-eds, and the book The

[40.0s - 45.5s]: Forest Unseen, as well as his recent book The Song of Trees, which we'll be talking

[45.5s - 46.2s]: about today.

[49.0s - 55.0s]: This book The Song of Trees has won the John Burrows Medal for Distinguished Natural

[55.0s - 63.8s]: History Writing, as well as public radio international science Friday, named one of the best science

[63.8s - 65.4s]: books of 2017.

[66.3s - 73.7s]: And Maria Popoba included the book in Brain Picking's favorite science books of 2017.

[74.7s - 79.9s]: And Forbes.com named the book One of the Ten Best Environment Climate Science and Conservation

[79.9s - 82.0s]: Books of 2017.

[82.7s - 89.1s]: And David it's so wonderful to have you here today and to know that so many in our communities

[89.1s - 94.1s]: and our global culture have responded to this book so positively.

[94.5s - 95.0s]: Well thank you.

[95.2s - 96.1s]: It's a delight to be here.

[96.9s - 103.6s]: And I know that you have a your undergrad degree in biology at the University of Oxford.

[104.4s - 107.6s]: And then you went on and did your graduate work at Cornell.

[108.7s - 110.7s]: What were you doing your graduate work in?

[111.4s - 116.4s]: My graduate work was mostly on the evolution of bird sounds.

[117.0s - 121.8s]: So birds of course structured their societies and communicate to one another mostly through

[121.8s - 126.0s]: acoustic means, some through feather displays and so on.

[126.1s - 127.6s]: But they're very acoustic creatures.

[127.8s - 134.2s]: And so I was interested in getting into that acoustic world and asking the birds how come

[134.2s - 136.2s]: this sound is so different from this one?

[136.3s - 139.4s]: How does species diverge in their sonic displays?

[139.9s - 145.9s]: So that was my initial foray, if you like, into the sonic world of other species.

[146.6s - 149.5s]: And I've since birds were the gateway drug, if you like.

[149.5s - 156.8s]: I've since moved into the sonic worlds of of trees and soundscapes and started in a

[157.4s - 163.8s]: very scientific mode of Cornell doing quantitative analyses of bird sounds and now has moved into

[163.8s - 170.1s]: a more open ended mode that includes sound recording and computers but a lot of listening

[170.1s - 173.8s]: out in unstructured ways out outside.

[174.5s - 181.1s]: You know, as we were planning over the last few days where we wanted to record this discussion,

[181.5s - 187.8s]: you suggested Boulder Creek right along this riparian corridor in downtown Boulder, Colorado,

[187.8s - 192.6s]: where we have plenty of cottonwoods and all kinds of other species as well.

[192.9s - 195.4s]: And why did you pick this spot?

[195.5s - 197.1s]: What made you think of this spot?

[197.9s - 204.5s]: This is an interesting confluence of human life and plant life and non-human animal life.

[204.6s - 208.3s]: Whenever I come to this place, they're always interesting creatures just that, you know,

[208.4s - 213.7s]: a minute ago a kingfish flew over, there's a little gathering of crows happening in a

[213.7s - 214.5s]: American region.

[214.9s - 220.9s]: And the trees here provide part of the atmosphere of the place.

[220.9s - 229.5s]: These really old cottonwoods that are integrated into animal and human environment.

[230.0s - 232.1s]: And so people are drawn to the park.

[232.2s - 236.2s]: Here, the library is here, the summer farmers market is right here.

[236.3s - 241.4s]: So there's an interesting drawing together of pathways that happens at this point.

[242.0s - 247.0s]: And so it's a delightful place to be, but it's also a very interesting place to be because

[247.6s - 253.9s]: many different life paths converge in this one place, including the life paths of trees.

[254.9s - 264.3s]: You know, I'm struck that you have a background and credentials in hard sciences in disciplines

[264.3s - 268.4s]: that generally are very technical and can be very reductionist.

[268.5s - 275.1s]: Yet when I'm reading your book, The Songs of Trees, I am struck by the lyricism, the

[275.1s - 282.1s]: poeticism that you're using in your prose to describe this magnificent tapestry of interconductivity

[282.7s - 284.6s]: that is the reality here on this planet.

[285.3s - 290.9s]: And I'm struck by my gosh, this is a scientist writing this and that isn't something I would

[290.9s - 292.3s]: have necessarily expected.

[292.9s - 294.4s]: How did that happen?

[295.0s - 302.5s]: Well, I think it's part of the structure of the world that the world is made from molecules

[302.5s - 308.3s]: and energy transfers and those are arranged in incredibly complicated architectures that

[308.3s - 309.9s]: have great deep history.

[310.9s - 317.1s]: The life on this planet is at least three and a half billion years old and that is poetry

[317.1s - 318.6s]: that is art.

[318.9s - 324.5s]: And so the world isn't divided into separate categories where academia is.

[325.0s - 329.2s]: You know, the division of science over here and then the division of humanities there and

[329.2s - 329.8s]: so forth.

[329.8s - 336.2s]: No, you know, a river has its rhythms, it has its music, it has atoms, has living creatures,

[336.3s - 338.9s]: it has DNA within it, environmental DNA.

[339.3s - 343.6s]: So all these different things that we divide into different disciplines and departments,

[344.3s - 345.8s]: I think are all present together.

[347.3s - 351.8s]: And even saying that they're present together, I think is a little bit of a falsehood because

[352.7s - 354.2s]: there is no separation.

[354.2s - 359.9s]: You know, the atoms are in the water, in the creek are in fact the music.

[360.1s - 362.7s]: They are moving with a particular rhythmicity.

[363.4s - 366.0s]: And so there is no separation.

[366.5s - 369.1s]: There's a blossoming coming from one place.

[369.6s - 376.5s]: And one of the great, the delights, the freedoms of writing in a more open-ended way in a nonfiction

[376.5s - 384.3s]: book rather than in a scientific paper is that some of those metaphors, analogies, rhythms

[384.3s - 386.5s]: can come to the surface of the writing.

[387.2s - 389.1s]: And it's entirely appropriate that it would.

[389.5s - 394.4s]: Whereas in a scientific paper, which is also a really wonderful place to be writing,

[394.8s - 396.5s]: but there's a particular form.

[396.9s - 404.3s]: Scientific papers are almost like the formal poetry of science in that there is a structure

[404.3s - 406.9s]: for what needs to go in which part of the paper.

[407.1s - 412.8s]: And you don't get to throw in wild speculations or interesting metaphors because that's not

[412.8s - 419.2s]: part of the agreed upon cultural rules for communication within that paper.

[419.3s - 422.9s]: And I think that's great that those rules are there for very good reasons.

[423.6s - 429.6s]: So scientific approach and then a poetic approach, I think a complementary, they work together.

[430.1s - 432.0s]: They're not in our position to one another.

[432.7s - 437.8s]: And that's one of the reasons to come out and stand on the side of a creek is that that truth

[437.8s - 439.7s]: becomes abundantly evident.

[440.2s - 444.6s]: Whereas sitting in a seminar room in a university or a high school or something,

[445.1s - 447.1s]: that those truths are hard to perceive.

[447.8s - 453.7s]: And that's the great challenge now in education, of course, is to break out of the boxes that

[453.7s - 459.7s]: we have created and embrace some of the actual connectivity of the world.

[459.7s - 464.9s]: And I think in some places we're doing a good job and in other ways education is

[464.9s - 467.1s]: utterly failing in that task.

[467.4s - 476.1s]: It's a fascinating, so it strikes me as something we see in the sciences as well as in the realm

[476.1s - 482.3s]: of business and economics that more and more of us are working diligently to resolve very

[482.3s - 486.2s]: challenging and complex issues related to sustainability on this planet.

[486.7s - 493.3s]: And I'm struck that some of our tools, things like financial models built in Excel,

[495.1s - 501.8s]: discussions and decision making in boardrooms, aren't necessarily bringing in the type of

[501.8s - 507.2s]: natural intelligence that is needed to deal with these challenges in our time.

[507.2s - 514.1s]: And what I hear you saying is that there's something specific and uniquely precious in our

[514.7s - 520.7s]: connecting to places, wild places like this one here that we're standing next to.

[521.3s - 529.6s]: Yes, and I think the key is that these different practices and ways of thinking about the world

[529.6s - 532.5s]: of relating to the world are not in opposition to one another.

[533.1s - 538.8s]: So modeling in an Excel spreadsheet or mapping forests using sophisticated,

[538.8s - 545.4s]: satellite technology. We need that way of approaching the world, but if that's all we have,

[546.0s - 554.2s]: then we're not drawing on the full set of intelligences, wisdoms, community understandings

[554.2s - 560.6s]: that exist within the human community of life, but also exist within, say, the root system of

[560.6s - 566.9s]: this cottonwood or in the relations of the invertebrate animals that live on the creek bed here.

[566.9s - 574.0s]: And an example that really brought that home to me in a way that I found very sad and disturbing

[574.0s - 581.4s]: was a few years ago I was part of a group of people that met in some corporate offices in New

[581.4s - 587.3s]: York City. We're on about the 50th floor. In that meeting room was going to be decided to fate

[587.3s - 594.0s]: of tens of thousands of acres of forest, in Tennessee, forest that was owned by a particular

[594.0s - 599.9s]: corporate entity. And there were some big environmental groups. There were lawyers there.

[600.4s - 606.5s]: There were the, of course, the people from the timber company. All discussing and showing

[606.5s - 613.7s]: interesting data on the PowerPoint screen and so forth about what's happening to the forest

[613.7s - 618.8s]: and what different people's perspectives were on trends and what the best thing for the forest was.

[619.8s - 625.2s]: The forest I felt was completely apt, almost completely absent there because most of the people

[625.2s - 631.4s]: in that room and particularly the decision makers had spent maybe one, perhaps two or three hours

[631.4s - 639.2s]: in the actual forest rather than those decisions being made by people who had a lifetime, maybe

[639.2s - 645.9s]: multiple lifetimes through conversation and ancestry, a relationship with the trees and the birds

[645.9s - 651.4s]: and the soil and the people, the lagers, the birdwatches, the people living downstream, the people

[651.4s - 657.8s]: living in the forest. All of these are different ways of understanding the forest and yet so much of

[657.8s - 666.6s]: that understanding just wasn't there. And so we were using human power but doing it in a way that

[666.6s - 675.8s]: I thought was, was unrooted from some guides to good use of power in the world. And that's just

[675.8s - 682.6s]: one example from my own trajectory. It happens again and again and often these are very well-meaning

[682.6s - 692.8s]: gatherings that have in a structure failed to open the door to sensory experience of the ecosystems

[692.8s - 698.8s]: that we're discussing. And if that door is closed we're likely to make poor decisions I think.

[699.4s - 706.8s]: This strikes me as such an important point for us to keep in mind as we're going forward.

[707.6s - 713.8s]: I'm mindful that you're writing about an experience of trees and forests and ecosystems

[714.8s - 721.5s]: is so oriented around sound, around the audible experience. And I've struck that the philosopher

[721.5s - 728.0s]: Kant a couple two or three centuries ago when speaking about intellectual enlightenment

[729.0s - 737.3s]: used this term unwondigke, this term of releasing from voicelessness. And I hear increasingly in

[737.3s - 744.1s]: conversations all around the planet that part of our challenge is that the rivers, the forests

[744.7s - 751.7s]: don't have that voice in our in our boardrooms all too often. And it's as if they can't walk and show

[751.7s - 758.0s]: up in the boardroom to give them voice it's incumbent upon us to go to them and listen. And

[758.0s - 762.9s]: boy if more of us would go to them and listen perhaps our decision making would invite it.

[762.9s - 768.9s]: Right. Yeah and you know that listening of course happens at many levels. At one level it's literally

[768.9s - 775.0s]: just opening one's ears to the acoustic signals of the world. And the great thing about sound of

[775.0s - 783.9s]: course is that it travels around and through and over barriers. So I might not see what is happening

[783.9s - 791.2s]: behind me or what is happening below the ground or inside the building here or just over the creek

[791.2s - 796.9s]: bank there but I can hear it. And so sound is the great revealer. It's also of course the great

[796.9s - 801.9s]: revealer of environmental injustice right who gets to listen to the traffic noise that you can't

[801.9s - 806.9s]: block out of your bedroom often it's lower income communities and so forth. So sound itself

[807.4s - 811.9s]: is an important part of communication but then there's a listening that goes beyond that

[811.9s - 817.8s]: that is about conversation and it's about gathering data. I mean I would argue that those excel

[817.8s - 824.5s]: spreadsheets and satellite imagery and so forth are another way of listening to the world. And it's

[824.7s - 830.0s]: not that we need to close the door to those ways and just go and sit by the creek and feel at

[830.0s - 837.6s]: one with the world not at all. We need data come through the scientific process but we also need

[838.1s - 846.0s]: our bodies to be in relationship with the places that are home to us. And without that bodily

[846.0s - 853.0s]: bodily connection we're cutting ourselves off from a lot of intelligence and delight because it's

[853.0s - 856.7s]: wonderful to be out here in the sunshine listening to the ducks and the crows and the river

[856.7s - 864.1s]: but also heartbreak because you cannot open yourself to the particularities of any place on this

[864.1s - 872.5s]: world without realizing oh this land was stolen from other people. This land the creek here is full

[888.6s - 894.2s]: brokenness that is emerged through that listening but if we don't open ourselves to that how do

[902.3s - 907.5s]: one thing I learned in the book listening to particular trees in different parts of the world

[908.4s - 914.9s]: that simultaneously I was filled with delight in these places but also came to understand in a way

[914.9s - 922.2s]: that was very difficult to take in how broken the world is not just through human actions in relation

[941.4s - 947.8s]: retreat indoors and onto computer screens is to to buffer ourselves from that to push it away

[948.5s - 955.0s]: but I think in a world that has so many crises those comfortable buffers of things that we need to

[998.3s - 1004.8s]: encapsulates this interconnectedness, this relationship phenomenon that we're describing here

[1004.8s - 1009.6s]: and I'm wondering would you want to read it for us or do you? I'd be happy to if you direct me to

[1009.6s - 1015.0s]: this. It's your voice and just this this paragraph here if you mind it's so beautiful.

[1015.9s - 1021.8s]: So this is a paragraph from the preface and the first part of the preface is setting up

[1021.8s - 1028.6s]: some of the rhythms and questions of the book about attending to the sounds of trees and I write

[1029.3s - 1038.7s]: in all these places tree songs emerge from relationship. Although tree trunks seemingly stand as

[1038.7s - 1047.7s]: detached individuals their lives subvert this atomistic view where all trees humans insects

[1047.7s - 1058.5s]: birds bacteria where all pluralities life is embodied network these living networks are not

[1058.5s - 1066.7s]: places of omniband benevolent oneness instead they are where the ecological and evolutionary tensions

[1067.3s - 1074.3s]: between cooperation and conflict are negotiated and resolved these struggles often result not

[1074.9s - 1083.3s]: in the evolution of stronger more disconnected selves but in the dissolution of the self into

[1093.9s - 1100.6s]: is a living community not a separate self and that's the great and attractive paradox of trees

[1141.5s - 1146.9s]: What's that experience that you've been practicing in your own life and that you're sharing with

[1146.9s - 1150.5s]: others through this book what is going on there when you're listening to trees?

segments.text: Welcome to the Y on Earth communities stewardship and sustainability podcast series.
Today we are visiting with Professor and author David George Haskell.
Hi David.
Hello and it's good to be with you.
Welcome to the show.
Thank you.
David is a British born American biologist author and professor of biology at
Sohani, the University of the South in Sohani, Tennessee.
In addition to scientific papers he has written essays, poems, op-eds, and the book The
Forest Unseen, as well as his recent book The Song of Trees, which we'll be talking
about today.
This book The Song of Trees has won the John Burrows Medal for Distinguished Natural
History Writing, as well as public radio international science Friday, named one of the best science
books of 2017.
And Maria Popoba included the book in Brain Picking's favorite science books of 2017.
And Forbes.com named the book One of the Ten Best Environment Climate Science and Conservation
Books of 2017.
And David it's so wonderful to have you here today and to know that so many in our communities
and our global culture have responded to this book so positively.
Well thank you.
It's a delight to be here.
And I know that you have a your undergrad degree in biology at the University of Oxford.
And then you went on and did your graduate work at Cornell.
What were you doing your graduate work in?
My graduate work was mostly on the evolution of bird sounds.
So birds of course structured their societies and communicate to one another mostly through
acoustic means, some through feather displays and so on.
But they're very acoustic creatures.
And so I was interested in getting into that acoustic world and asking the birds how come
this sound is so different from this one?
How does species diverge in their sonic displays?
So that was my initial foray, if you like, into the sonic world of other species.
And I've since birds were the gateway drug, if you like.
I've since moved into the sonic worlds of of trees and soundscapes and started in a
very scientific mode of Cornell doing quantitative analyses of bird sounds and now has moved into
a more open ended mode that includes sound recording and computers but a lot of listening
out in unstructured ways out outside.
You know, as we were planning over the last few days where we wanted to record this discussion,
you suggested Boulder Creek right along this riparian corridor in downtown Boulder, Colorado,
where we have plenty of cottonwoods and all kinds of other species as well.
And why did you pick this spot?
What made you think of this spot?
This is an interesting confluence of human life and plant life and non-human animal life.
Whenever I come to this place, they're always interesting creatures just that, you know,
a minute ago a kingfish flew over, there's a little gathering of crows happening in a
American region.
And the trees here provide part of the atmosphere of the place.
These really old cottonwoods that are integrated into animal and human environment.
And so people are drawn to the park.
Here, the library is here, the summer farmers market is right here.
So there's an interesting drawing together of pathways that happens at this point.
And so it's a delightful place to be, but it's also a very interesting place to be because
many different life paths converge in this one place, including the life paths of trees.
You know, I'm struck that you have a background and credentials in hard sciences in disciplines
that generally are very technical and can be very reductionist.
Yet when I'm reading your book, The Songs of Trees, I am struck by the lyricism, the
poeticism that you're using in your prose to describe this magnificent tapestry of interconductivity
that is the reality here on this planet.
And I'm struck by my gosh, this is a scientist writing this and that isn't something I would
have necessarily expected.
How did that happen?
Well, I think it's part of the structure of the world that the world is made from molecules
and energy transfers and those are arranged in incredibly complicated architectures that
have great deep history.
The life on this planet is at least three and a half billion years old and that is poetry
that is art.
And so the world isn't divided into separate categories where academia is.
You know, the division of science over here and then the division of humanities there and
so forth.
No, you know, a river has its rhythms, it has its music, it has atoms, has living creatures,
it has DNA within it, environmental DNA.
So all these different things that we divide into different disciplines and departments,
I think are all present together.
And even saying that they're present together, I think is a little bit of a falsehood because
there is no separation.
You know, the atoms are in the water, in the creek are in fact the music.
They are moving with a particular rhythmicity.
And so there is no separation.
There's a blossoming coming from one place.
And one of the great, the delights, the freedoms of writing in a more open-ended way in a nonfiction
book rather than in a scientific paper is that some of those metaphors, analogies, rhythms
can come to the surface of the writing.
And it's entirely appropriate that it would.
Whereas in a scientific paper, which is also a really wonderful place to be writing,
but there's a particular form.
Scientific papers are almost like the formal poetry of science in that there is a structure
for what needs to go in which part of the paper.
And you don't get to throw in wild speculations or interesting metaphors because that's not
part of the agreed upon cultural rules for communication within that paper.
And I think that's great that those rules are there for very good reasons.
So scientific approach and then a poetic approach, I think a complementary, they work together.
They're not in our position to one another.
And that's one of the reasons to come out and stand on the side of a creek is that that truth
becomes abundantly evident.
Whereas sitting in a seminar room in a university or a high school or something,
that those truths are hard to perceive.
And that's the great challenge now in education, of course, is to break out of the boxes that
we have created and embrace some of the actual connectivity of the world.
And I think in some places we're doing a good job and in other ways education is
utterly failing in that task.
It's a fascinating, so it strikes me as something we see in the sciences as well as in the realm
of business and economics that more and more of us are working diligently to resolve very
challenging and complex issues related to sustainability on this planet.
And I'm struck that some of our tools, things like financial models built in Excel,
discussions and decision making in boardrooms, aren't necessarily bringing in the type of
natural intelligence that is needed to deal with these challenges in our time.
And what I hear you saying is that there's something specific and uniquely precious in our
connecting to places, wild places like this one here that we're standing next to.
